title: 115_hr2886
content: The Act may be cited as the "Children's Act for Responsible Employment of 2017" or the "CARE Act of 2017". Definitions are amended. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to define 'Oppressive child labor' as hazardous or detrimental employment conditions for employees aged 14-17. SEC. 3 revises the age requirement for child agricultural employment and repeals the waiver provision for hand harvest laborers. Revised age requirements for child labor in agriculture and non-agricultural employment under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Repeal of waiver provision for child labor age requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. SEC. 4. INCREASED CIVIL PENALTIES FOR CHILD LABOR VIOLATIONS. Section 16(e) of the Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to increase civil penalties for child labor violations. The penalties range from $500 to $15,000 per employee for violations, and from $15,000 to $50,000 for violations causing serious injury, illness, or death of employees under 18 years old. Penalties may be doubled for repeated or willful violations. The amendment expands the definition of "serious injury" to include "serious illness" in Section 16(e) of the Fair Labor Standards Act, increasing civil penalties for child labor violations. Penalties range from $500 to $15,000 per employee for violations, and from $15,000 to $50,000 for violations causing harm to employees under 18 years old. Penalties may be doubled for repeated or willful violations. SEC. 5 of the Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to impose special criminal penalties for aggravated child labor violations, including imprisonment for up to 5 years or a fine for violations causing death or serious harm to employees under 18. Additionally, SEC. 6 introduces a new Pesticide-Related Worker Protection Standard. SEC. 6 introduces a new Pesticide-Related Worker Protection Standard prohibiting the employment of children under 18 as pesticide handlers. The Secretary of Labor may issue rules to implement the Fair Labor Standards Act amendments, with rules taking effect within 30 days of publication. Violations of the Act after the rule's effective date will be subject to the amendments. State laws providing greater protections for employees will not be preempted by these amendments.
